Short answer: Adding a tape.watch(x) will make this work, so:

with tf.GradientTape() as tape:
    x = tf.constant(100.)
    tape.watch(x)
    y = log1pexp(x)

print(tape.gradient(y, [x]))

As per the documentation for GradientTape, trainable Variable objects are watched automatically, but tensors aren't.

@RamNathaniel : While we figure out how to make it harder to trip over this quirk, I hope you can continue to make progress (and it's fine to call tape.watch(x) in graph as well, so the same code will work).

body:
Short answer: Adding a [`tape.watch(x)`](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/GradientTape#watch) will make this work, so:

```python
with tf.GradientTape() as tape:
    x = tf.constant(100.)
    tape.watch(x)
    y = log1pexp(x)

print(tape.gradient(y, [x]))
```

As per the [documentation for `GradientTape`](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/GradientTape), trainable `Variable` objects are watched automatically, but tensors aren't.

@RamNathaniel : While we figure out how to make it harder to trip over this quirk, I hope you can continue to make progress (and it's fine to call `tape.watch(x)` in graph as well, so the same code will work).
